paragraph.content: with the leave of the Court of Appeal, on any ground which involves a question of fact alone, or a question of mixed law and fact, or on any other ground which appears to the Court of Appeal to be a sufficient ground of appeal,

subsection.continued: but if the judge who made the order under section 38F grants a certificate that the case is fit for appeal on a ground which involves a question of fact, or a question of mixed law and fact, an appeal lies under this section without the leave of the Court of Appeal.

section.name: s38I
section.heading: Grounds for allowing appeal
section.leadIn: The Court of Appeal shall allow an appeal against an order made under section 38F if it thinks that the order should be set aside on the ground of a wrong decision on any question of law or of fact or of mixed law and fact: (Amended L.N. 345 of 1982)
section.proviso: Provided that the Court of Appeal may, notwithstanding that it is of opinion that the point raised in the appeal might be decided in favour of the appellant, dismiss the appeal if it considers that no miscarriage of justice has actually occurred.

section.name: s38J
section.heading: Procedure on appeal
section.content: Subject to sections 38H and 38I, the procedure on an appeal shall with all necessary modifications be that applicable to an appeal against conviction for an offence on indictment under section 82 of the Criminal Procedure Ordinance (Cap. 221), and an appeal against sentence under section 83G of the Criminal Procedure Ordinance (Cap. 221).

section.name: s38K
section.heading: Amendment of Fifth Schedule

subsection.content: The Chief Executive in Council may by order amend the Fifth Schedule. (Amended 13 of 1999 s. 3)

Any question as to what constitutes an excessive quantity of dangerous drugs shall be determined by reference to the quantity specified in the Fifth Schedule at the time of the finding and, in the case of a finding before the date on which this Part came into operation, to the quantity so specified on that date.

section.name: s38L
section.heading: Offences on Hong Kong ships
section.content: Anything which would constitute an offence under this Ordinance if done on land in any part of Hong Kong shall constitute that offence if done on a Hong Kong ship.

section.name: s38M
section.heading: Ships used for illicit traffic

subsection.content: This section applies to a Hong Kong ship, a ship registered in a jurisdiction other than Hong Kong which is a party to the Vienna Convention (a Convention state) and a ship not registered in any jurisdiction.

subsection.leadIn: A person is guilty of an offence if on a ship to which this section applies, wherever it may be, he—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: has a dangerous drug in his possession;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is in any way knowingly concerned in the carrying or concealing of a dangerous drug on the ship; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: manufactures a dangerous drug or does or offers to do an act preparatory to or for the purpose of manufacturing a dangerous drug,

subsection.continued: knowing or having reasonable grounds to believe that the drug is intended to be imported or has been exported contrary to this Ordinance or the law of any jurisdiction outside Hong Kong.

subsection.leadIn: A person who is guilty of an offence—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: under subsection (2)(a) shall be liable—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: on conviction on indictment to a fine of $1,000,000 and to imprisonment for 7 years; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 3 years; (Amended E.R. 4 of 2019)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: under subsection (2)(b) shall be liable—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: on conviction on indictment to a fine of $5,000,000 and to imprisonment for life; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine of $500,000 and to imprisonment for 3 years; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: under subsection (2)(c) shall be liable on conviction on indictment to a fine of $5,000,000 and to imprisonment for life.

section.name: s38N
section.heading: Enforcement powers

subsection.content: The powers conferred on a member of the Customs and Excise Service by this Ordinance shall be exercisable in relation to any ship to which section 38L or 38M applies for the purpose of detecting and the taking of appropriate action in respect of the offences mentioned in those sections.

subsection.leadIn: Those powers shall not be exercised outside the waters of Hong Kong in relation to a ship registered in a Convention state except with the authority of the Secretary for Justice and he shall not give his authority unless that state has in relation to that ship—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: requested the assistance of Hong Kong for the purpose mentioned in subsection (1); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: authorized Hong Kong to act for that purpose.

subsection.content: In giving his authority pursuant to a request or authorization from a Convention state the Secretary for Justice shall impose such conditions or limitations on the exercise of the powers as may be necessary to give effect to any conditions or limitations imposed by that state.

The Secretary for Justice may, either of his own motion or in response to a request from a Convention state, authorize a Convention state to exercise, in relation to a Hong Kong ship, powers corresponding to those conferred on a member of the Customs and Excise Service by this Ordinance but subject to such conditions or limitations, if any, as the Secretary for Justice may impose.

Subsection (4) is without prejudice to any agreement made or which may be made on behalf of Hong Kong whereby Hong Kong undertakes not to object to the exercise by any jurisdiction in relation to a Hong Kong ship of powers corresponding to those conferred on a member of the Customs and Excise Service by this Ordinance.

The powers conferred on a member of the Customs and Excise Service by this Ordinance shall not be exercised in the territorial waters of any jurisdiction other than Hong Kong without the authority of the Secretary for Justice and he shall not give his authority unless that other jurisdiction has consented to the exercise of those powers.

section.name: s38O
section.heading: Jurisdiction and prosecutions

subsection.content: Proceedings under this Part in respect of an offence on a ship may be taken, and the offence may for all incidental purposes be treated as having been committed, in Hong Kong.
No such proceedings shall be instituted except by or with the consent of the Secretary for Justice.

Notwithstanding subsection (2) a person may be charged with an offence under this Part and may be arrested therefor, or a warrant for his arrest may be issued and executed, and any such person may be remanded in custody or on bail notwithstanding that the consent of the Secretary for Justice to the institution of a prosecution for the offence has not been obtained, but no such person shall be remanded in custody or on bail for longer than 3 days on such charge unless in the meantime the consent of the Secretary for Justice aforesaid has been obtained.

When a person is brought before a magistrate before the Secretary for Justice has consented to the prosecution, the charge shall be explained to the person accused but he shall not be called upon to plead and the provision of the law for the time being in force relating to criminal procedure shall be modified accordingly.

section.name: s38P
section.heading: Interpretation of Part VB

subsection.leadIn: In this Part—
subsection.def: Convention state (公約國) has the meaning given in section 38M;
Hong Kong ship (香港船舶) means a ship registered or licensed in Hong Kong;

the Vienna Convention (《維也納公約》) means the United Nations Convention against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances which was signed at Vienna on 20 December 1988. (Amended E.R. 4 of 2019)

subsection.content: If in any proceedings under this Part any question arises whether any jurisdiction is a state or is a party to the Vienna Convention, a certificate issued by or under the authority of the Secretary for Justice shall be conclusive evidence on that question. (Amended L.N. 362 of 1997)

part.name: P6
part.heading: Conspiracy to Commit Offence under Ordinance, False Statements, Aiding, etc. Offence under Corresponding Law, Joint Trial in Certain Cases and Conviction of Other Offences

section.name: s39
section.heading: Conspiracy
section.content: Any person convicted of conspiracy to commit an offence under this Ordinance shall be liable to the penalty prescribed for that offence and any special rules of evidence which apply with respect to the proof of that offence under this Ordinance shall apply in like manner to the proof of conspiracy to commit such offence.

section.name: s40
section.heading: False statements, and aiding, abetting, etc. offence under corresponding law

subsection.leadIn: Any person who—

paragraph.name: a
b
c
paragraph.content: aids, abets, counsels or procures the commission in a place outside Hong Kong of an offence punishable under a corresponding law in force in that place, or does an act preparatory to, or in furtherance of, an act which if committed in Hong Kong would constitute an offence under section 4 or 6,

subsection.continued: shall be guilty of an offence.

subsection.content: Any person who is guilty of an offence under subsection (1)(a) or (b) shall be liable on conviction to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 3 years.

subsection.leadIn: Any person who is guilty of an offence under subsection (1)(c) shall be liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment, to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 15 years; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction, to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 3 years.

section.name: s41
section.heading: Joint trial of offences in certain cases
section.content: Notwithstanding anything in the Magistrates Ordinance (Cap. 227) or any other law, where it is alleged that 2 or more persons have committed distinct offences under section 4, 8, 35 or 36 in the same place and at about the same time, the charges for such offence against such persons may be tried together.

section.name: s42
section.heading: Conviction of offence other than that charged

subsection.content: If on the trial of a charge for an offence specified in the second column of the Third Schedule the defendant is acquitted, but it is proved that the defendant is guilty of any offence specified opposite thereto in the third column of that Schedule or of being a party to any such offence, he shall be convicted of such offence or of being a party to any such offence and shall be liable to be punished accordingly.
The references in the Third Schedule to numbered sections and subsections shall be construed to include every offence under the section or subsection so numbered in this Ordinance.
Nothing in this section shall exclude the application to any offence of any other law authorizing a person to be found guilty of an offence other than that with which he is charged.

section.name: s43
section.heading: Certificate of corresponding law
section.leadIn: A document purporting to be issued by or on behalf of the government of a country and purporting to state the terms of a corresponding law in force in that country shall be admitted in evidence, in proceedings for an offence under this Ordinance before any court, on its production by the prosecution without further proof, and such document shall be conclusive evidence—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that it is issued by or on behalf of the government of that country;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that the terms of such law are as stated in the document; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: that any facts stated in the document to constitute an offence under such law do constitute such offence.

section.name: s45
section.heading: Presumption concerning manufacture of dangerous drug
section.content: Any person who is proved to have been manufacturing or doing an act preparatory to the manufacture of a dangerous drug shall, until the contrary is proved, be presumed to have known the nature of such drug.

section.name: s47
section.heading: Presumption of possession and knowledge of dangerous drug

subsection.leadIn: Any person who is proved to have had in his physical possession—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: anything containing or supporting a dangerous drug;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the keys of any baggage, briefcase, box, case, cupboard, drawer, safe-deposit box, safe or other similar container containing a dangerous drug,

subsection.continued: shall, until the contrary is proved, be presumed to have had such drug in his possession.

subsection.content: Any person who is proved or presumed to have had a dangerous drug in his possession shall, until the contrary is proved, be presumed to have known the nature of such drug.
The presumptions provided for in this section shall not be rebutted by proof that the defendant never had physical possession of the dangerous drug.

section.name: s49A
section.heading: Interpretation
section.leadIn: In this Part, unless the context otherwise requires—
section.def: Commissioner (專員) means the Commissioner for Narcotics;

def.name: ConfidentialInformation
def.leadIn: confidential information (機密資料) means information which is recorded by the Registry or a reporting agency in respect of any person and which relates to any one or more of the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the use, or alleged use, by that person of a dangerous drug;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the conviction of that person for an offence under this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the care, treatment or rehabilitation of that person by reason of his use of a dangerous drug;

section.def: drug abuser (濫用藥物者) means a person who is the subject of any confidential information;

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: in relation to the Registry, means any public officer employed in—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the Narcotics Division of the Security Bureau of the Government; or (Amended L.N. 362 of 1997)

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the Digital Policy Office of the Government; and (Amended 80 of 1997 s. 102; L.N. 131 of 2004; L.N. 101 of 2024)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: in relation to a reporting agency, means any person employed in the agency, whether full-time or part-time and whether paid or unpaid, in—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the care, treatment or rehabilitation of persons who use, or have used, dangerous drugs;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the preparation, maintenance or analysis of records of confidential information,

paragraph.continued: and also means any person who is being trained by the agency in any such matter;

section.def: reporting agency (呈報機構) means any body or organization specified in the Fourth Schedule;

def.name: ReportingAgencyDirector
def.leadIn: reporting agency director (呈報機構負責人)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in relation to the Department of Health of the Government, means the Director of Health and any person to whom he has delegated the supervision of any records of confidential information which are kept by that Department; (Amended L.N. 76 of 1989)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in relation to the Social Welfare Department of the Government, means the Director of Social Welfare and any person to whom he has delegated the supervision of any records of confidential information which are kept by that Department; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in relation to any other reporting agency, means the person who is for the time being in charge of the administration of that agency and any person to whom he has delegated the supervision of any records of confidential information which are kept by that agency.

section.name: s49B
section.heading: Central Registry of Drug Abuse

subsection.leadIn: There shall be a Central Registry of Drug Abuse, the purposes of which shall include—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the collection, collating and analysis of confidential information supplied by reporting agencies and of information on drug abuse and its treatment supplied by other sources; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the publication of statistical information on drug abuse and on various forms of treatment of drug abuse.

subsection.content: The Central Registry of Drug Addicts existing at the commencement# of the Dangerous Drugs (Amendment) Ordinance 1981 (65 of 1981) and maintained by the Narcotics Division of the Security Bureau of the Government shall be the Central Registry of Drug Abuse for the purposes of subsection (1). (Amended L.N. 362 of 1997)

section.name: s49C
section.heading: Immunity of records from search and from production in court

subsection.content: No search warrant shall be issued, or if issued be executed, in respect of any record of confidential information which is kept by the Registry or by a reporting agency.

Save as provided in this Part, no power, or right, of search conferred by any law shall authorize the search of records of confidential information which are kept by the Registry or by a reporting agency.

subsection.leadIn: No process shall lie in any proceedings to compel production of any record of confidential information which is kept by the Registry or by a reporting agency, and no such record, nor any information obtained therefrom, shall be admissible in evidence, save—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in proceedings for an offence under this Part; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where the record is the subject of an order of the Secretary for Justice which is in force under section 49G, (Amended L.N. 362 of 1997)

subsection.continued: but nothing in this subsection shall render admissible anything which is otherwise inadmissible.

section.name: s49D
section.heading: Prohibition against disclosure of records

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (2), any person who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: discloses any record of confidential information which is kept by the Registry or a reporting agency, or supplies to any person information obtained from any such record; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: permits access to any such record,

subsection.continued: commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 2 and to imprisonment for 6 months. (Amended E.R. 4 of 2019)

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (1) shall not apply where the disclosure is made, or access is permitted—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in accordance with an authorization given under section 49E;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in accordance with an authorization given under section 49F;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in accordance with an order of the Secretary for Justice made under section 49G; (Amended L.N. 362 of 1997)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: to the Commissioner or a reporting agency director, or to an employee of the Registry or of a reporting agency, for the purpose of treating a drug abuser for his drug addiction or of assisting him in his rehabilitation;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: to a medical practitioner for the purpose of providing medical treatment for any person, or to a coroner or a medical practitioner for the purpose of inquiring into the cause of death of a drug abuser;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: in proceedings for an offence under this Part; (Amended 10 of 2001 s. 32)

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: to the Director of Social Welfare or any public officer under section 18 of the Drug Dependent Persons Treatment and Rehabilitation Centres (Licensing) Ordinance (Cap. 566). (Added 10 of 2001 s. 32)

section.name: s49E
section.heading: Disclosure of information for research purposes

subsection.leadIn: Where the Commissioner is satisfied, upon an application being made to him in writing, that disclosure of confidential information which is recorded by the Registry—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is sought by the applicant in the interests of bona fide research; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: can be made in a manner that does not disclose the identity of any drug abuser,

subsection.continued: he may if he thinks fit authorize any employee of the Registry to disclose to the applicant confidential information in that manner.

subsection.leadIn: Where a reporting agency director is satisfied, upon an application being made to him in writing, that disclosure of confidential information which is recorded by the reporting agency of which he is director—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is sought by the applicant in the interests of bona fide research; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: can be made in a manner that does not disclose the identity of any drug abuser,

subsection.continued: he may if he thinks fit authorize any employee of the reporting agency to disclose to the applicant confidential information in that manner.

subsection.leadIn: An authorization issued under subsection (1) or (2)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: shall be in writing;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: shall identify the information, or the nature of the information, to which it applies;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: shall state the manner in which the authorized disclosure is to be made so as to prevent the identity of any drug abuser from being disclosed;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: may be revoked at any time.

section.name: s49F
section.heading: Access to records with consent of addict

subsection.leadIn: Where a drug abuser gives his consent for confidential information which concerns him to be disclosed to a person, or for a purpose, specified in such consent—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Commissioner may, if he thinks fit, authorize such disclosure from the records of the Registry; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a reporting agency director may, if he thinks fit, authorize such disclosure from the records of his reporting agency.

subsection.leadIn: An authorization given under subsection (1) shall be in writing and shall state—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: whether the disclosure is to be made from the records of the Registry or of a reporting agency, and, in the latter case, the name of that agency;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: where the disclosure is to be made—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: from the Registry, that the authorization is given by the Commissioner;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: by a reporting agency, the name of the reporting agency director who gives the authorization;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the name of the person to whom the disclosure is to be made;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the extent of the confidential information which may be disclosed;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the purpose of the disclosure; and

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: that the authorization may be revoked at any time, and the circumstances in which, or date when, it will expire if not revoked.

subsection.content: An authorization given by the Commissioner or any reporting agency director under subsection (1) may be revoked at any time.

subsection.leadIn: A drug abuser’s consent for the purposes of subsection (1) shall be in writing and—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: be given—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: in the case of a drug abuser who is unmarried and under the age of 19 years, both by him and by a parent or other person standing in loco parentis to him;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: in the case of a drug abuser who is by reason of mental disability unable to give the consent himself, by a person having lawful authority over his affairs;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: be read over to the person giving consent by or in the presence of the person who authorizes disclosure under subsection (1); and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: bear the signature, fingerprint or mark of the person giving consent.

section.name: s49G
section.heading: Access to records by order of Secretary for Justice

subsection.leadIn: Where in connection with the investigation or prosecution of a crime the Secretary for Justice is of the opinion that, because of the gravity of the crime or for any other reason, the public interest requires that any confidential information should be disclosed he may, after considering any representations which may be made by—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Commissioner; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the reporting agency director of the reporting agency (if any) which supplied the confidential information to the Registry or from whose records the disclosure is to be made,

subsection.continued: make an order in accordance with this section.

subsection.content: The power conferred upon the Secretary for Justice by subsection (1) shall be exercised by the Secretary for Justice personally.

subsection.leadIn: An order under subsection (1) shall be in writing and may direct—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Commissioner and any reporting agency director who has been given the opportunity to make representations to the Secretary for Justice under subsection (1); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any employee of the Registry or, as the case may be, of a reporting agency,

subsection.continued: to disclose in such manner, to such person, and at such time and place as the order specifies, such records as are specified in the order.

subsection.content: An order under subsection (1) shall be served personally on every person who is directed by it to disclose any record.

Any person who fails without reasonable excuse to comply with an order under subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 2 and to imprisonment for 6 months. (Amended E.R. 4 of 2019)

section.name: s49H
section.heading: Consent of Secretary for Justice required for prosecution
section.content: No prosecution for an offence under this Part shall be instituted except with the consent of the Secretary for Justice.

section.name: s49I
section.heading: Amendment of Fourth Schedule
section.content: The Secretary for Security may by order published in the Gazette amend the Fourth Schedule.

section.name: s50
section.heading: Amendment of First, Second and Third Schedules

subsection.content: The Chief Executive may by order published in the Gazette amend the First and Third Schedules. (Replaced 65 of 1981 s. 3. Amended 62 of 1994 s. 7; 13 of 1999 s. 3)
The Secretary for Security may by order published in the Gazette amend the Second Schedule. (Added 62 of 1994 s. 7)

section.name: s51
section.heading: Regulations

subsection.leadIn: The Chief Executive in Council may make regulations for all or any of the following matters— (Amended 13 of 1999 s. 3)

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: the preservation of such registers and records and of other documents kept, issued or made pursuant to or for the purposes of this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: requirements with respect to prescriptions;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the marking of packages and bottles containing dangerous drugs;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the period for which a licence issued under section 18 is valid;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: the fees payable on the issue of a licence under section 18;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: the form of any document, other than a licence or certificate, required by, under or for the purposes of this Ordinance.

subsection.content: Regulations made under this section may provide that a contravention of specified provisions thereof shall be an offence and may provide penalties therefor not exceeding a fine of $450,000 and imprisonment for 3 years. (Amended L.N. 201 of 1996)

section.name: s52
section.heading: Powers of authorized officers

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this Ordinance, any police officer and any member of the Customs and Excise Service may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: stop, board and search any ship, aircraft, vehicle or train which has arrived in Hong Kong (not being a ship of war or a military aircraft), and remain thereon as long as it remains in Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: search any person arriving in Hong Kong or about to depart from Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: search any thing imported into or to be exported from Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: stop, board and search any ship, aircraft, vehicle or train if he has reason to suspect that there is therein an article liable to seizure;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: without a warrant issued under subsection (1E) where it would not be reasonably practicable to obtain such a warrant, enter and search any place or premises if he has reason to suspect that there is therein an article liable to seizure; or (Amended 62 of 1994 s. 8)

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.leadIn: stop and search any person, and search the property of any person, if—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: he has reason to suspect that such person has in his actual custody an article liable to seizure; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: such person is found in any ship, aircraft, vehicle, train, place or premises in which an article liable to seizure is found.

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.content: For the purposes of enabling a person to be searched under subsection (1)(f)(i), a police officer of or above the rank of inspector or a member of the Customs and Excise Service of or above the rank of inspector may request a registered medical practitioner or nurse registered or enrolled or deemed to be registered or enrolled under the Nurses Registration Ordinance (Cap. 164), to examine the body cavities of that person. (Added 40 of 1982 s. 3)

subsection.name: 1B
subsection.content: A medical practitioner or nurse requested to examine the body cavities of a person under subsection (1A) may search the rectum, vagina, ears and any other body cavity of that person. (Added 40 of 1982 s. 3)

subsection.name: 1C
subsection.content: A medical practitioner or nurse carrying out an examination of a person at the request, under subsection (1A), of a police officer or member of the Customs and Excise Service who appears to be lawfully engaged in the performance of his duty shall not be bound to inquire whether or not the police officer or member is acting lawfully or within the scope of his duty. (Added 40 of 1982 s. 3)

subsection.name: 1D
subsection.content: A police officer or member of the Customs and Excise Service may detain a person in respect of whom a request is to be or has been made to a medical practitioner or nurse under subsection (1A) for such time as may reasonably be necessary to permit a medical practitioner or nurse to complete an examination of the body cavities of that person under this section. (Added 40 of 1982 s. 3)

subsection.name: 1E
subsection.content: Where it appears to any magistrate upon the oath of any person that there is reasonable cause to suspect that in any place there is an article liable to seizure under this Ordinance, or with respect to which an offence has been committed or is about to be committed against the provisions of this Ordinance, the magistrate may, by his warrant directed to any police officer or to any member of the Customs and Excise Service, empower such officer or member by day or by night to enter the place named in the warrant and there to search for and seize, remove and detain any such article. (Added 62 of 1994 s. 8)

subsection.leadIn: For the purpose of enabling a ship or aircraft to be searched under subsection (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Commissioner of Customs and Excise or the Commissioner of Police may by order in writing under his hand detain a ship for not more than 12 hours or an aircraft for not more than 6 hours; and (Amended 40 of 1985 s. 9)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Chief Secretary for Administration may, by order in writing under his hand, detain a ship or aircraft for further periods of not more than 12 hours in the case of a ship or not more than 6 hours in the case of an aircraft. (Amended L.N. 362 of 1997)

subsection.continued: Any order made under this subsection shall state the times from which and for which the order is effective.

subsection.content: Any public officer may seize, remove and detain any thing if he has reason to suspect that such thing is an article liable to seizure.
Any public officer authorized in writing by the Director may uproot, seize, remove and destroy any plant of the genus cannabis or the opium poppy.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this Ordinance, any public officer authorized in writing by the Director may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: enter, inspect and search any place or premises occupied by—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a person authorized by virtue of section 22(1)(a), (b) or (c) or (5A) or by virtue of section 24(1); (Amended 2 of 1992 s. 11)

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: a person whose authorization as aforesaid has been withdrawn under section 33 and the withdrawal suspended;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: a person by whom any such person as aforesaid is employed; or

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: a person to whom a licence has been issued under this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: require the production of, and inspect, any register, record, book, prescription or other document kept or made pursuant to the requirements, or for the purposes, of this Ordinance or any other document relating to dealings in a dangerous drug by or on behalf of any such person as aforesaid; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: inspect any stocks of a dangerous drug in the possession of any such person as aforesaid.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this Ordinance, any public officer authorized in writing by the Director may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: enter, inspect and search a hospital or institution specified in the Second Schedule or any place or premises occupied for the purposes of any such hospital or institution;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: require the production of, and inspect, any register, record, book, prescription or other document kept or made in any such hospital or institution pursuant to the requirements, or for the purposes, of this Ordinance or any other document relating to dealings in a dangerous drug for the purposes of such hospital or institution; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: inspect any stocks of a dangerous drug in any such hospital or institution or in any such place or premises.

subsection.content: An authorization given by the Director under this section may be given to a police officer, member of the Customs and Excise Service or public officer by name or may be given to any police officer, member of the Customs and Excise Service or other public officer for the time being holding such rank or public office as the Director may specify, and may extend to all the powers specified in subsection (2), (4) or (5), as the case may be, or to such of those powers as the Director may specify.

subsection.leadIn: Any public officer may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: break open any outer or inner door of or in any place or premises which he is empowered by this section to enter and search;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: forcibly board any ship, aircraft, vehicle or train which he is empowered by this section to board and search;

paragraph.name: c
d
paragraph.content: detain every person found in any place or premises which he is empowered by this section to search until the same has been searched; and

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: detain every person on board any ship, aircraft, vehicle or train which he is empowered by this section to search, and prevent any person from approaching or boarding such ship, aircraft, vehicle or train, until it has been searched.

subparagraph.content: An examination of the body cavities of a person under this section shall, unless that person otherwise consents, be carried out by a medical practitioner or nurse of the same sex as that person.

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: Where a female has consented, under sub-paragraph (i), to an examination of her body cavities by a medical practitioner or nurse of the opposite sex, such examination shall be in the presence of another female.

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: Subject to paragraph (a), no female shall be searched under this section except by a female.

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: No person shall be searched under this section in a public place if he objects to being so searched. (Replaced 40 of 1982 s. 3)

subsection.name: 9A
subsection.content: The provisions of this Ordinance (including section 56) which could, but for this subsection, apply to a thing seized under this section shall not apply to the thing if it has been so seized on the ground that it is suspected to be specified property referred to in paragraph (d) of the definition of article liable to seizure. (Added 89 of 1995 s. 35)

subsection.name: 9B
subsection.content: For the avoidance of doubt, it is hereby declared that where a thing referred to in subsection (9A) is released under section 24C(4) of the Drug Trafficking (Recovery of Proceeds) Ordinance (Cap. 405), that subsection shall not operate to prevent the application of the provisions of this Ordinance (including this section and section 56) to that thing at any time on or after such release. (Added 89 of 1995 s. 35)

subsection.leadIn: In this section—

def.name: ArticleLiableToSeizure
def.leadIn: article liable to seizure (可予扣押的物件) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any dangerous drug referred to in section 55;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any money or thing liable to forfeiture under this Ordinance or forfeiture or confiscation under a corresponding law; (Amended 89 of 1995 s. 35)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: any thing which is or contains evidence of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: an offence under this Ordinance or a corresponding law;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: a drug trafficking offence within the meaning of the Drug Trafficking (Recovery of Proceeds) Ordinance (Cap. 405); (Replaced 89 of 1995 s. 35)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: any specified property within the meaning of Part IVA of the Drug Trafficking (Recovery of Proceeds) Ordinance (Cap. 405); (Added 89 of 1995 s. 35)

subsection.def: Commissioner of Customs and Excise (海關關長) includes a Deputy Commissioner of Customs and Excise and an Assistant Commissioner of Customs and Excise; (Added 40 of 1985 s. 9. Amended L.N. 362 of 1997; 18 of 2014 s. 89)
Commissioner of Police (警務處處長) includes a deputy or assistant commissioner of police.

section.name: s53
section.heading: Failure to comply with requirement under section 52 and obstruction of authorized officer

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: fails to comply with a requirement of a public officer under section 52(5)(b) or (6)(b); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: obstructs a public officer in the exercise of any power conferred on him by section 52,

section.continued: shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction to a fine at level 1 and to imprisonment for 6 months. (Amended E.R. 4 of 2019)

section.name: s53A
section.heading: Surrender of travel document

subsection.content: A magistrate may, on the application of the Commissioner of Police or the Commissioner of Customs and Excise, by written notice require a person who is the subject of an investigation in respect of a specified offence alleged or suspected to have been committed by him to surrender to the Commissioner of Police or Commissioner of Customs and Excise any travel document in his possession. (Amended 40 of 1985 s. 9)
The matter of an application under subsection (1) shall be substantiated by the oath of the applicant.
A notice under subsection (1) shall be served personally on the person to whom it is addressed.
A person on whom a notice under subsection (1) is served shall comply with such notice forthwith.

subsection.name: 4A
subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (8), a person to whom a notice under subsection (1) is addressed shall not leave Hong Kong, whether or not the notice has been served on him under subsection (3), before the expiry of a period of 3 months from the date of the notice unless—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an application made under section 53B(1) for the return of a travel document is granted; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an application made under section 53C(1) for permission to leave Hong Kong is granted. (Added 10 of 2005 s. 39)

subsection.content: If a person on whom a notice under subsection (1) has been served fails to comply with the notice forthwith, he may be arrested and taken before a magistrate. (Amended 10 of 2005 s. 39)

subsection.leadIn: Where a person is taken before a magistrate under subsection (5), the magistrate shall, unless such person thereupon complies with the notice under subsection (1) or satisfies the magistrate that he does not possess a travel document, by warrant commit him to prison there to be safely kept—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: until the expiry of the period of 28 days from the date of his committal to prison as aforesaid; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: until such person complies with the notice under subsection (1) and a magistrate, by order in that behalf, orders and directs the Commissioner of Correctional Services to discharge such person from prison (which order shall be sufficient warrant for the Commissioner of Correctional Services so to do), (Amended L.N. 30 of 1982)

subsection.continued: whichever occurs first.

subsection.content: Upon the surrender of a travel document under this section, the Commissioner of Police or the Commissioner of Customs and Excise, as the case may be, shall issue a receipt identifying the travel document. (Amended 40 of 1985 s. 9)

subsection.name: 7A
subsection.content: Subject to subsection (8), a travel document surrendered to the Commissioner of Police or the Commissioner of Customs and Excise in compliance with a notice under subsection (1) may be detained for a period of 3 months from the date of the notice unless an application made under section 53B(1) for the return of the travel document is granted. (Added 10 of 2005 s. 39)

The period of 3 months referred to in subsections (4A) and (7A) may be extended for not more than 2 further periods of 3 months if a magistrate, on application by the Commissioner of Police or the Commissioner of Customs and Excise, is satisfied that the investigation could not reasonably have been completed before the date of such application and authorizes such extension. (Amended 40 of 1985 s. 9; 10 of 2005 s. 39)
All proceedings before a magistrate under this section shall be conducted in chambers.

subsection.leadIn: In this section and sections 53B and 53C— (Amended 10 of 2005 s. 39)
subsection.def: Commissioner of Customs and Excise (海關關長) includes a Deputy Commissioner of Customs and Excise and an Assistant Commissioner of Customs and Excise; (Added 40 of 1985 s. 9. Amended L.N. 362 of 1997; 18 of 2014 s. 90)
Commissioner of Police (警務處處長) includes a deputy or assistant commissioner of police;

specified offence (指明罪行) means any offence punishable under any section of this Ordinance, on conviction on indictment, with imprisonment for a term of 15 years or any greater punishment, and aiding, abetting, counselling or procuring the commission by another of any such offence;
travel document (旅行證件) means a passport or other document issued for the purpose of travel which establishes the identity or nationality of the holder.

section.name: s53B
section.heading: Application for return of travel document

subsection.content: A person who has surrendered his travel document in accordance with section 53A may at any time make written application to the Commissioner of Police or the Commissioner of Customs and Excise, as the case may be, for its return and every such application shall contain a statement of the grounds on which it is made. (Amended 40 of 1985 s. 9)

Before determining an application under subsection (1), the Commissioner of Police or the Commissioner of Customs and Excise may require that any matter of fact relied on in the application shall be substantiated by statutory declaration. (Amended 40 of 1985 s. 9)

Any person aggrieved by the refusal of an application under subsection (1) may, within 14 days of being informed of such refusal, appeal to a magistrate against that refusal and the magistrate may, upon considering the grounds of the application and any evidence which may be adduced in relation thereto by or on behalf of either party, order that the travel document be returned.
The decision of a magistrate in relation to an appeal under this section shall be final.

section.name: s53C
section.heading: Application for permission to leave Hong Kong

subsection.content: Without prejudice to section 53B, a person on whom a notice under section 53A(1) is served may at any time make written application to the Commissioner of Police or the Commissioner of Customs and Excise, as the case may be, for permission to leave Hong Kong and every such application shall contain a statement of the grounds on which it is made.

Before determining an application under subsection (1), the Commissioner of Police or the Commissioner of Customs and Excise may require that any matter of fact relied on in the application shall be substantiated by statutory declaration.

Any person aggrieved by the refusal of an application under subsection (1) may, within 14 days of being informed of such refusal, appeal to a magistrate against that refusal and the magistrate may, upon considering the grounds of the application and any evidence which may be adduced in relation thereto by or on behalf of either party, order that the person be permitted to leave Hong Kong.
The decision of a magistrate in relation to an appeal under this section shall be final.

section.name: s54
section.heading: Chemical tests and handwriting

subsection.leadIn: Any police officer not below the rank of inspector or any member of the Customs and Excise Service not below the rank of inspector may require any person whom he reasonably suspects to be guilty of an offence under this Ordinance— (Amended 13 of 1973 s. 2)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to have his finger nails pared and his hands washed in water for the purpose of analysis of such finger nails and water; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to give a specimen of his handwriting for the purpose of comparison.

subsection.content: Any person who fails to comply with a requirement under subsection (1) shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction to a fine at level 1. (Amended E.R. 4 of 2019)

section.name: s54A
section.heading: Court to consider report of the Commissioner of Correctional Services in the case of certain drug offences

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (1A), no sentence, other than a non-custodial sentence, shall be imposed on a person for an offence against section 8 or 36 unless the court has first considered a report of the Commissioner of Correctional Services on the suitability of such person for cure and rehabilitation and on the availability of places at addiction treatment centres (as defined in the Drug Addiction Treatment Centres Ordinance (Cap. 244)). (Amended L.N. 30 of 1982; 24 of 1987 s. 4)

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.leadIn: Subsection (1) shall not apply where a person is convicted of an offence against section 8 or 36 or of offences against both those sections and that person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is convicted in the same proceedings of any other offence and is sentenced for that other offence to imprisonment for more than 9 months; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is at the time of conviction serving a term of imprisonment of more than 9 months,

subsection.continued: but, in such a case, the court may if it thinks fit consider a report specified in subsection (1) before sentencing that person for the offence against section 8 or 36. (Added 24 of 1987 s. 4)

subsection.name: 1B
subsection.content: Where a court is required or has decided to consider a report under this section before sentencing a person but has not received such a report, it shall remand that person in the custody of the Commissioner of Correctional Services for such period, not exceeding 3 weeks, as the court thinks necessary to enable such a report to be made. (Added 24 of 1987 s. 4)

The Commissioner of Correctional Services shall, in his report under this section, inform the court whether or not a detention order under the Drug Addiction Treatment Centres Ordinance (Cap. 244) has previously been made in respect of the person to whom the report relates. (Amended L.N. 30 of 1982; 24 of 1987 s. 4)
Section 4(3) of the Drug Addiction Treatment Centres Ordinance (Cap. 244) shall not apply where a report is obtained under this section.

def.name: NoncustodialSentence
def.leadIn: In this section, non-custodial sentence (非拘留性判決) means one or more of the following sentences— (Amended E.R. 4 of 2019)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a fine;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a probation order under section 3 of the Probation of Offenders Ordinance (Cap. 298);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a suspended sentence of imprisonment under section 109B of the Criminal Procedure Ordinance (Cap. 221).

section.name: s54AA
section.heading: Taking of urine samples

subsection.leadIn: In any investigation in respect of an offence committed or believed to have been committed, a urine sample may be taken from a person only if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a police officer of or above the rank of superintendent or a member of the Customs and Excise Service of or above the rank of superintendent (authorizing officer) authorizes it to be taken;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the appropriate consent is given; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a magistrate gives approval under subsection (7) for it to be taken.

subsection.leadIn: An authorizing officer may only give an authorization as required under subsection (1)(a) if he has reasonable grounds—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for suspecting that the person from whom the urine sample is to be taken has committed a serious arrestable offence; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for believing that the sample will tend to confirm or disprove the commission of the offence by that person.

subsection.content: An authorizing officer must give an authorization pursuant to subsection (2) in writing.

subsection.leadIn: Where an authorization has been given pursuant to subsection (2), a police officer or a member of the Customs and Excise Service may request the person from whom the urine sample is to be taken and that person’s parent or guardian if he is under the age of 18 years, to give the appropriate consent to the taking of the sample and the officer or the member, in making the request, shall inform the person and his parent or guardian, as the case may be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: of the nature of the offence in which the person is suspected to have committed;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that there are reasonable grounds to believe that the sample will tend to confirm or disprove the commission of the offence by that person;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: that he may or may not give his consent to the taking of the sample;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: that if he consents to the taking of the sample, he may at any time withdraw that consent before the sample is taken;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: that the sample will be analysed and the information derived from such analysis may provide evidence that might be used in criminal proceedings for such offence or any other offence in relation to dangerous drugs; and

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: that he may make a request to a police officer or a member of the Customs and Excise Service for access to the information derived from the sample.

subsection.content: The person from whom a urine sample was taken pursuant to subsection (1) is entitled to access to the information derived from the sample.
The appropriate consent must be given in writing and signed by the person or persons giving the consent.

Where an authorization and the appropriate consent as required under subsection (1)(a) and (b) have been given, a police officer or a member of the Customs and Excise Service shall make an application to a magistrate in accordance with the Seventh Schedule for the magistrate’s approval as required under subsection (1)(c) and the magistrate may give his approval in accordance with that Schedule.
A urine sample may only be taken from a person by a police officer or a member of the Customs and Excise Service of the same sex as that person.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in relation to a person who has attained the age of 18 years, the consent of that person;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in relation to a person who has not attained the age of 18 years, the consent both of that person and of his parent or guardian;

subsection.def: serious arrestable offence (嚴重的可逮捕罪行) means an offence in relation to dangerous drugs for which a person may under or by virtue of any law be sentenced to imprisonment for a term not less than 7 years.

section.name: s54AB
section.heading: Use and disposal of urine samples and information derived from analysis

subsection.content: Without prejudice to subsection (4), no person shall have access to, dispose of or use a urine sample taken pursuant to section 54AA except for the purposes of forensic analysis in the course of an investigation of any offence in relation to dangerous drugs.

subsection.leadIn: Without prejudice to subsection (4), no person shall have access to, disclose or use any information derived from the forensic analysis of a urine sample taken pursuant to section 54AA except for the purposes of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any proceedings for an offence in relation to dangerous drugs; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: making the information available to the person to whom the information relates.

subsection.content: Any person who contravenes subsection (1) or (2) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

subsection.leadIn: Whether or not a urine sample taken pursuant to section 54AA or any information derived from the forensic analysis of the sample has been destroyed under subsection (5), no person shall use the sample or information in any proceedings for an offence in relation to dangerous drugs after—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: it is decided that a person from whom the sample was taken shall not be charged with any offence in relation to dangerous drugs;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: if the person has been charged with one or more such offences—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the charge or all the charges, as the case may be, is or are withdrawn;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the person is discharged by a court before conviction of the offence or all the offences, as the case may be; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the person is acquitted of the offence or all the offences, as the case may be, at trial or on appeal,

subsection.leadIn: The Commissioner of Police or the Commissioner of Customs and Excise, as the case may be, shall take reasonable steps to ensure that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a urine sample taken pursuant to section 54AA; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: all information derived from the forensic analysis of the sample,

subsection.continued: which may be retained by him or on his behalf are destroyed as soon as practicable after—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.leadIn: if the person from whom the sample was taken has not been charged with any offence in relation to dangerous drugs, the expiry of—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: subject to subparagraph (B), 12 months from the date on which the sample is taken (the relevant period); or

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: such further period or periods as may be extended under subsection (6) (the extended period);

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.leadIn: if the person has been charged with one or more offences in relation to dangerous drugs within the relevant period and the extended period, if any—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: the charge or all the charges, as the case may be, is or are withdrawn;

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: the person is discharged by a court before conviction of the offence or all the offences, as the case may be; or

subparagraph.name: C
subparagraph.content: the person is acquitted of the offence or all the offences, as the case may be, at trial or on appeal,

subsection.content: A police officer of or above the rank of chief superintendent or a member of or above the rank of chief superintendent of the Customs and Excise Service may extend or further extend the relevant period for not more than 6 months for each extension if he is satisfied on reasonable grounds that it is necessary to the continuing investigation of the offence or offences in relation to which the sample was taken that the sample and the information derived from the forensic analysis of the sample be retained.

subsection.leadIn: Without prejudice to the operation of subsections (5) and (6), if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person from whom a urine sample was taken pursuant to section 54AA has been convicted of one or more offences in relation to dangerous drugs; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: there is no other charge against the person—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: in relation to dangerous drugs; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: which renders the retention of the sample necessary,

subsection.continued: then the Commissioner of Police or the Commissioner of Customs and Excise, as the case may be, shall take reasonable steps to ensure that the sample which may be retained by him or on his behalf is destroyed as soon as practicable after the conclusion of all proceedings (including any appeal) arising out of the conviction.

section.name: s54AC
section.heading: Amendment of Seventh Schedule
section.content: The Chief Executive in Council may by order published in the Gazette amend the Seventh Schedule but any order to amend that Schedule shall be subject to the approval of the Legislative Council.

section.name: s55
section.heading: Dangerous drugs forfeited by law
section.leadIn: Any dangerous drug in respect of which an offence under this Ordinance is being or has been committed, and any dangerous drug in transit—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: which was accompanied, when it was brought into Hong Kong, by a false export authorization or diversion certificate or by an export authorization or diversion certificate which was obtained by fraud or by the wilful misrepresentation or omission of a material particular; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: which, not being accompanied by an export authorization or diversion certificate when it was brought into Hong Kong, was being conveyed for an unlawful purpose or was in transit for the purpose of being imported into another country in contravention of the laws of that country,

section.continued: shall, with effect from the seizure thereof under section 52, be forfeited to the Government.

section.name: s56
section.heading: Forfeiture of articles, etc., used in connection with offence

subsection.leadIn: A court may (whether or not any person has been convicted of such offence) order to be forfeited to the Government—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: any money or other property received or possessed by any person as the result or product of,

subsection.continued: an offence under this Ordinance or a drug trafficking offence within the meaning of the Drug Trafficking (Recovery of Proceeds) Ordinance (Cap. 405). (Amended 89 of 1995 s. 36)

subsection.content: An order under subsection (1) for the forfeiture of a thing may include a term permitting a specified person or persons to redeem such thing on such conditions, including conditions as to the payment of the value or a proportion of the value thereof to the Government, as the court may think fit.
The court may require that notice of an application for forfeiture under subsection (1) shall be given in such manner as it thinks fit.

The Chief Executive in Council may, in his absolute discretion and after any proceedings under this Ordinance are concluded, entertain and give effect to any moral claim to or in respect of any money, thing or other property which has been forfeited to the Government.

section.name: s56A
section.heading: Sentencing in respect of specified offences

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (5), where a person (other than a minor) has been convicted of a specified offence and—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a court is satisfied beyond reasonable doubt as to any information furnished under subsection (2); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any such information is agreed by the person,

subsection.continued: then the court—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: shall have regard to such information when it passes a sentence on the person for the offence; and

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: may, if it thinks fit, pass a sentence on the person for that offence that is more severe than the sentence it would, in the absence of such information, have passed.

subsection.leadIn: Information which may be furnished to a court under this subsection is any information which proves that the commission of the relevant specified offence involved a minor and, without limiting the generality of the foregoing, the information may relate to any of the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the procuring, supplying or trafficking by whatever means of a dangerous drug for or to a minor for possession or otherwise by a person;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a person obtaining by whatever means a dangerous drug from a minor;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: provision by a person to a minor of any pipe, equipment or apparatus fit and intended for the smoking, inhalation, ingestion or injection of a dangerous drug;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a person intentionally or unintentionally employing, hiring, using, persuading, enticing, or coercing a minor in the commission of a specified offence or the avoidance of detection or apprehension of such an offence;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: use of a minor in assisting the operation or management of premises which are used as a divan or for unlawful trafficking, manufacturing, or storage of a dangerous drug.

subsection.content: Only information that would be admissible in evidence in criminal proceedings (including proceedings in respect of sentencing) may be furnished to the court under subsection (2).

subsection.leadIn: Where the prosecution seeks to furnish information to a court under subsection (2), the court shall allow the person convicted of the relevant specified offence an opportunity to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: object to the reception of the information; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where such information is received by the court, furnish other information regarding that first-mentioned information.

subsection.content: A sentence passed pursuant to subsection (1) shall not exceed the maximum penalty permitted by law for the relevant specified offence.

This section shall operate without prejudice to any other information that may be furnished to a court before a person is sentenced, or to any other information to which a court shall or may have regard when sentencing a person for any offence.

subsection.leadIn: The power of a court to pass a more severe sentence under subsection (1) shall extend to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: conspiracy to commit;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: inciting another to commit;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: attempting to commit; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: aiding, abetting, counselling or procuring the commission of,

subsection.continued: a specified offence.

subsection.content: This section shall not apply to a person who is convicted of a specified offence committed before the commencement of this section.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: court (法庭) includes a magistrate;
specified offence (指明罪行) means any offence under section 4, 4A, 5, 6, 8, 9, 35, 36 or 37.

section.name: s57
section.heading: Protection of informers

subsection.leadIn: Save as provided in subsection (2)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: no information for an offence under this Ordinance shall be admitted in evidence in any civil or criminal proceeding; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: no witness in any civil or criminal proceeding shall be obliged—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: to disclose the name or address of any informer who has given information to the police with respect to an offence under this Ordinance or of any person who has assisted the police in any way with respect to such an offence; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: to answer any question if the answer thereto would lead, or would tend to lead, to discovery of the name or address of such informer or person,

paragraph.continued: if, in either case, such informer or person is not himself a witness in such proceeding,

subsection.continued: and, if any books, documents or papers which are in evidence or liable to inspection in any civil or criminal proceeding contain an entry in which any such informer or person is named or described or which might lead to his discovery, the court shall cause all such passages to be concealed from view or to be obliterated so far as may be necessary to protect the informer or such person from discovery.

subsection.content: If in any proceeding before a court for an offence under this Ordinance the court, after full inquiry into the case, is satisfied that an informer wilfully made a material statement which he knew or believed to be false or did not believe to be true, or if in any other proceeding a court is of opinion that justice cannot be fully done between the parties thereto without disclosure of the name of an informer or a person who has assisted the police, the court may permit inquiry and require full disclosure concerning the informer or such person.

section.name: s58
section.heading: Power of Chief Executive to give directions

subsection.content: The Chief Executive may give to any public officer, other than a judge, a District Judge or a magistrate, such directions as he thinks fit with respect to the exercise or performance of his powers, functions or duties under this Ordinance, either generally or in any particular case.
A public officer shall, in the exercise or performance of his powers, functions or duties under this Ordinance, comply with any directions given by the Chief Executive under subsection (1).

paragraph.name: i
ii

paragraph.name: iv
paragraph.content: by substitution in the aniline ring with alkyl, alkoxy, alkenedioxy, halogeno or haloalkyl groups;

paragraph.name: vi

subsection.leadIn: any compound (not being a compound for the time being specified in subparagraph (a)) structurally derived from pethidine by modification in any of the following ways, that is to say—

part.heading: Preparations to which Ordinance Applies with Modifications

section.name: s13
section.leadIn: A preparation of not more than one of the substances specified in paragraph 19 or 20, when—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: compounded with one or more other ingredients in such a way that the preparation has no, or a negligible, risk of abuse and that the substance cannot be recovered by readily applicable means or in a yield which would constitute a risk to health; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: containing not more than 100 milligrams of the substance per dosage unit and with a concentration of not more than 0.5% in undivided preparations. (Amended 62 of 1994 s. 9; E.R. 4 of 2019)

section.name: s14
section.content: A preparation of cocaine containing not more than 0.1% of cocaine calculated as cocaine base, being a preparation compounded with one or more other ingredients in such a way that the preparation has no, or a negligible, risk of abuse and that the cocaine cannot be recovered by readily applicable means or in a yield which would constitute a risk to health. (Amended E.R. 4 of 2019)

section.name: s15
section.content: A preparation of medicinal opium or of morphine containing (in either case) not more than 0.2% of morphine calculated as anhydrous morphine base, being a preparation compounded with one or more other ingredients in such a way that the preparation has no, or a negligible, risk of abuse and that the opium or, as the case may be, the morphine cannot be recovered by readily applicable means or in a yield which would constitute a risk to health. (Amended E.R. 4 of 2019)

section.name: s16
section.content: A preparation of diphenoxylate containing, per dosage unit, not more than 2.5 milligrams of diphenoxylate calculated as base and not less than 25 micrograms of atropine sulphate. (Amended L.N. 324 of 1980)

section.name: s16A
section.content: A preparation of difenoxin containing, per dosage unit, not more than 0.5 milligram of difenoxin calculated as base and a quantity of atrophine sulphate equivalent to at least 5% of the dose of difenoxin. (Added L.N. 321 of 1977. Amended L.N. 324 of 1980)

section.name: s16C
section.content: A preparation of Propiram containing not more than 100 milligrams of propiram per dosage unit and compounded with at least the same amount of methylcellulose. (Added L.N. 185 of 1983)

section.name: s16D
section.content: A preparation of gamma-butyrolactone containing not more than 0.1% of gamma-butyrolactone, being a preparation compounded with one or more other ingredients in such a way that the preparation has no, or a negligible, risk of abuse and that the gamma-butyrolactone cannot be recovered by readily applicable means or in a yield which would constitute a risk to health. schedule.name: sch7
schedule.heading: Application for and Giving of a Magistrate’s Approval for the Taking of a Urine Sample

section.name: s1
section.content: An application under section 54AA(7) of this Ordinance must be made in Form 1. A copy of the authorization duly given pursuant to section 54AA(2) of this Ordinance and of appropriate consent duly given and signed under section 54AA(6) of this Ordinance must be exhibited to Form 1.

section.name: s2
section.content: Form 1 together with the exhibits referred to in section 1 must be submitted to a magistrate.

section.name: s3
section.leadIn: A magistrate, on receiving the application, may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: give his approval if he is satisfied that—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: an authorization has been duly given pursuant to section 54AA(2) of this Ordinance;

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: for suspecting that the person from whom the urine sample is to be taken has committed a serious arrestable offence; and

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: for believing that the sample will tend to confirm or disprove the commission of the offence by that person; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the appropriate consent has been duly given under section 54AA(6) of this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: order that an inter partes hearing shall be conducted in private for the purposes of determining whether the approval should be given or not if he considers that it is necessary in the interest of justice to do so; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: reject the application if he thinks fit to do so.

section.name: s4
section.content: An order made under section 3(b) must specify a hearing date and must be served on the applicant and the respondent not less than a period as may be directed by the magistrate before the specified hearing date.

section.name: s5
section.content: Where an order has been duly served under section 4, the applicant and the respondent must attend before the magistrate on the hearing date specified in the order. The respondent may be represented by his legal representative. The applicant and the respondent (or his legal representative, if any) may make representations at the hearing.

section.name: s6
section.leadIn: The magistrate, upon hearing the parties, may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: give his approval if he is satisfied that—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: an authorization has been duly given pursuant to section 54AA(2) of this Ordinance;

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: for suspecting that the person from whom the urine sample is to be taken has committed a serious arrestable offence; and

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: for believing that the sample will tend to confirm or disprove the commission of the offence by that person; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the appropriate consent has been duly given under section 54AA(6) of this Ordinance; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: reject the application if he thinks fit to do so.

section.name: s7
section.content: The approval under sections 3(a) and 6(a) must be given in Form 2.
